title: 106_s1898
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Interstate Transportation of Dangerous Criminals Act of 2000" or "Jeanna's Act." Congress finds that States are increasingly using private prisoner transport companies for violent prisoners, leading to escapes and the need for oversight by the Attorney General. While most prefer law enforcement officers, fiscal or logistical concerns may require specialized private transport companies. Private prisoner transport companies may be used by governmental entities for moving violent prisoners due to fiscal or logistical concerns. If a government entity chooses to use a private transport company, the company should be regulated to ensure public safety. In this Act, definitions are provided for terms like "crime of violence," "private prisoner transport company," and "violent prisoner." These definitions clarify the scope and meaning of these terms within the context of the Act. Federal regulation of prisoner transport companies. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant organizations, will establish regulations for transporting violent prisoners across state lines. These regulations will cover background checks, drug testing, and training requirements for employees of prisoner transport companies. The regulations for transporting violent prisoners across state lines include preemployment drug testing, minimum training standards, and restrictions on employee duty hours. Training will focus on areas such as restraints, searches, use of force, CPR, map reading, and defensive driving. Employee duty hour restrictions will not exceed current rules under the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Act. The regulations for transporting violent prisoners across state lines include restrictions on duty hours, minimum personnel standards for supervision, employee uniform requirements, and categories of violent prisoners. The regulations for transporting violent prisoners include standards for employee uniforms, identification, clothing for prisoners, restraints, notification to local law enforcement, and escape protocols. The regulations for transporting violent prisoners include requirements for double-locked handcuffs, advance notification to local law enforcement, immediate notification in case of escape, and minimum safety standards in accordance with Federal and State law. Regulations do not include subsection (b)(6) requirements. The private prisoner transport company contracted for the transport of the escaped violent prisoner must adhere to minimum safety standards as per Federal and State law. Federal regulations for private prisoner transport companies must not be stricter than those for the United States Marshals Service, Federal Bureau of Prisons, and Immigration and Naturalization Service. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT.

Violators of the regulations in this Act may face a civil penalty up to $10,000 per violation, along with prosecution costs. They must also reimburse any entity that incurred expenses in apprehending an escaped violent prisoner due to the violation of regulations.
